content: The "Civil Rights History Project Act of 2009" recognizes the importance of individuals standing up for their rights and beliefs, citing the Civil Rights movement as a prime example of this principle in action. Key events such as the Montgomery Bus Boycott, sit-ins, Freedom Rides, March on Washington, drive for voting rights in Mississippi, and March to Selma are highlighted. The Civil Rights movement from the 1950s to the 1960s, with events like the Montgomery Bus Boycott, sit-ins, Freedom Rides, March on Washington, voting rights in Mississippi, and March to Selma, showcased individuals standing up for justice. While well-known leaders like Thurgood Marshall, Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., and Rosa Parks played significant roles, there were many other impactful but lesser-known participants. The participants in the Civil Rights movement have valuable first-hand memories that can provide a detailed history of the important and tumultuous period. It is in the Nation's interest to collect oral histories from individuals involved in the movement. The recording of oral histories from individuals involved in the Civil Rights movement will provide a rich and detailed history of the important period.
